title: 112_s1445
content: The Act is titled the "Raechel and Jacqueline Houck Safe Rental Car Act of 2011" and includes definitions. The "Raechel and Jacqueline Houck Safe Rental Car Act of 2011" defines terms such as "covered vehicle," "defect," "motor vehicle," "motor vehicle safety," "motor vehicle safety standard," "person," and "rental company." A covered vehicle is a motor vehicle rated at 26,000 pounds gross vehicle weight or less, rented or leased without a driver, and part of a fleet of 5 or more vehicles used for rental or lease purposes by a rental company. PROHIBITION ON RENTAL, LEASE, AND SALE OF DEFECTIVE CARS AND TRUCKS. Prohibition on rental, lease, or sale of covered vehicles with safety defects unless remedied prior to transaction. Exceptions apply if Secretary's notification is challenged in civil action. Rental companies must promptly notify renters of safety defects in vehicles and offer a comparable alternative vehicle at no extra cost until the issue is resolved. Rental companies must provide a comparable alternative vehicle at no extra cost to the renter, lessee, or authorized driver until the safety defect is fixed. This section will be effective 60 days after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT BY FEDERAL TRADE COMMISSION. Violation of section 3 of this Act will be treated as a violation of a rule under the Federal Trade Commission Act regarding unfair or deceptive acts. The Federal Trade Commission will enforce this Act with the same powers and duties as under the Federal Trade Commission Act. Penalties for violations will be in accordance with the Federal Trade Commission Act. Nothing in this section limits the Commission's authority under other laws. The attorney general of a State can bring a civil action in a US district court for injunctive relief under this Act. Prior notice to the Federal Trade Commission is required before initiating such action. The attorney general of a State must provide notice and a copy of the complaint before filing a civil action. If not feasible, notice must be given immediately upon initiating the action. The Federal Trade Commission can intervene in the action and file petitions for appeal. Nothing in this section should prevent the attorney general from taking action. The attorney general of a State can take action in civil or criminal cases, but cannot bring a separate suit if the Federal Trade Commission or the United States is already pursuing the same violation. Nothing in this section should hinder the attorney general from exercising their powers under state laws. SEC. 6. CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not prevent individuals from seeking remedies under Federal or State law. SEC. 7. NATIONAL HIGHWAY TRAFFIC SAFETY ADMINISTRATION REPORT ON SALES OF MOTOR VEHICLES TO RENTAL COMPANIES WITHOUT STANDARD SAFETY FEATURES. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must submit a report to Congress within 180 days regarding the sales of motor vehicles to rental companies without standard safety features. The report will include details on buying practices, implications on consumer safety, and recommendations for regulatory and legislative actions to protect consumers. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration will report to Congress on rental companies selling vehicles with safety defects before recalls. The Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration will submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. The report will focus on rental companies selling vehicles that may have safety defects or not comply with safety standards. Rental companies must notify customers if their vehicles are affected, and the report will cover the period from awareness of the issue to the receipt of a notification from the Secretary of Transportation. The report required by the Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment will analyze the frequency of sales of vehicles with safety defects by rental companies, discuss the impact on consumers, and provide recommendations for legislative and administrative actions to address or mitigate such sales. The Administrator will submit a follow-up report to Congress within 1 year, analyzing sales of covered vehicles and providing recommendations for legislative and administrative actions to address safety defects. The follow-up report to Congress will include an analysis of differences in findings, effects of the Act on covered vehicle sales, and recommendations for addressing safety defects.
